current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To streamline and ensure onshore energy permitting, provide for onshore leasing certainty, and give certainty to oil shale development for American energy security, economic development, and job creation, and for other purposes.

text.#text: Notwithstanding any other law, the

text.#text: In this chapter—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , regarding agency action (as defined for the purposes of that section) affecting a covered energy project on Federal lands of the United States; and

term.#tail: means a civil action containing a claim under

text.#text: the term

term.#tail: means the leasing of Federal lands of the United States for the exploration, development, production, processing, or transmission of oil, natural gas, wind, or any other source of energy, and any action under such a lease, except that the term does not include any disputes between the parties to a lease regarding the obligations under such lease, including regarding any alleged breach of the lease.

text.#text: the term
Venue for any covered civil action shall lie in the district court where the project or leases exist or are proposed.

header.#text: Exclusive venue for certain civil actions relating to covered energy projects

text.#text: To ensure timely redress by the courts, a covered civil action must be filed no later than the end of the 90-day period beginning on the date of the final Federal agency action to which it relates.
The court shall endeavor to hear and determine any covered civil action as expeditiously as possible.

header.#text: Expedition in hearing and determining the action

text.#text: In any judicial review of a covered civil action, administrative findings and conclusions relating to the challenged Federal action or decision shall be presumed to be correct, and the presumption may be rebutted only by the preponderance of the evidence contained in the administrative record.

In a covered civil action, the court shall not grant or approve any prospective relief unless the court finds that such relief is narrowly drawn, extends no further than necessary to correct the violation of a legal requirement, and is the least intrusive means necessary to correct that violation. In addition, courts shall limit the duration of preliminary injunctions to halt covered energy projects to no more than 60 days, unless the court finds clear reasons to extend the injunction. In such cases of extensions, such extensions shall only be in 30-day increments and shall require action by the court to renew the injunction.

header.#text: Limitation on injunction and prospective relief

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: do not apply to a covered civil action, nor shall any party in such a covered civil action receive payment from the Federal Government for their attorneys’ fees, expenses, and other court costs.

short-title.#text: Federal Lands Jobs and Energy Security Act

text.#text: This title may be cited as the

header.#text: Policies regarding buying, building, and working for America

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that—

text.#text: It is the intent of the

this title will support a healthy and growing United States domestic energy sector that, in turn, helps to reinvigorate American manufacturing, transportation, and service sectors by employing the vast talents of United States workers to assist in the development of energy from domestic sources;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make every effort to promote the development of onshore American energy, and shall take into consideration the socioeconomic impacts, infrastructure requirements, and fiscal stability for local communities located within areas containing onshore energy resources; and

text.#text: to ensure a robust onshore energy production industry and ensure that the benefits of development support local communities, under this title, the

the Congress will monitor the deployment of personnel and material onshore to encourage the development of American manufacturing to enable United States workers to benefit from this title through good jobs and careers, as well as the establishment of important industrial facilities to support expanded access to American resources.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall when possible, and practicable, encourage the use of United States workers and equipment manufactured in the United States in all construction related to mineral resource development under this title.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Federal Lands Jobs and Energy Security

short-title.#text: Planning for American Energy Act of 2013

text.#text: This title may be cited as the

header.#text: Onshore domestic energy production strategic plan

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: as
, and by inserting after

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by redesignating

header.#text: Quadrennial Strategic Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (hereafter in this section referred to as
with regard to lands administered by the

, shall develop and publish every 4 years a Quadrennial Federal Onshore Energy Production Strategy. This Strategy shall direct Federal land energy development and department resource allocation in order to promote the energy and national security of the United States in accordance with
’s mission of promoting the multiple use of Federal lands as set forth in the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall consult with the

on the projected energy demands of the United States for the next 30-year period, and how energy derived from Federal onshore lands can put the United States on a trajectory to meet that demand during the next 4-year period. The
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Energy Information Administration

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall consider how Federal lands will contribute to ensuring national energy security, with a goal for increasing energy independence and production, during the next 4-year period.

text.#text: In developing this Strategy, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall determine a domestic strategic production objective for the development of energy resources from Federal onshore lands. Such objective shall be—

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

text.#text: the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in domestic production of oil and natural gas from the Federal onshore mineral estate, with a focus on lands held by the
the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in domestic coal production from Federal lands;
the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in domestic production of strategic and critical energy minerals from the Federal onshore mineral estate;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

text.#text: the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in megawatts for electricity production from each of the following sources: wind, solar, biomass, hydropower, and geothermal energy produced on Federal lands administered by the
the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in unconventional energy production, such as oil shale;

the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in domestic production of oil, natural gas, coal, and other renewable sources from tribal lands for any federally recognized Indian tribe that elects to participate in facilitating energy production on its lands;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the
; and

text.#text: the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in production of helium on Federal lands administered by the
the best estimate, based upon commercial and scientific data, of the expected increase in domestic production of geothermal, solar, wind, or other renewable energy sources from

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and including any other lands deemed by the Territory or State of Hawaii, as the case may be, to be included within that definition) that the agency or department of the government of the State of Hawaii that is responsible for the administration of such lands selects to be used for such energy production.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 203 of the Hawaiian Homes Commission Act, 1920

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: et seq.)
shall consult with the
regarding the methodology used to arrive at its estimates for purposes of this section.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Energy Information Administration

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has the authority to expand the energy development plan to include other energy production technology sources or advancements in energy on Federal lands.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall include in the Strategy a plan for addressing new demands for transmission lines and pipelines for distribution of oil and gas across Federal lands to ensure that energy produced can be distributed to areas of need.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that federally recognized Indian tribes may elect to set their own production objectives as part of the Strategy under this section. The
shall work in cooperation with any federally recognized Indian tribe that elects to participate in achieving its own strategic energy objectives designated under this subsection.

text.#text: It is the sense of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall also take all necessary actions to achieve these production objectives unless the

determines that it is not in the national security and economic interests of the United States to increase Federal domestic energy production and to further decrease dependence upon foreign sources of energy. In administering this section, the relevant Secretary shall only consider leasing Federal lands available for leasing at the time the lease sale occurs.

text.#text: The relevant Secretary shall have all necessary authority to make determinations regarding which additional lands will be made available in order to meet the production objectives established by strategies under this section. The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall solicit the input of affected States, federally recognized Indian tribes, local governments, and the public.

text.#text: In developing each strategy, the

header.#text: State, federally recognized Indian tribes, local government, and public input

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall report annually to the
and the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: on the progress of meeting the production goals set forth in the strategy. The
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall identify in the report projections for production and capacity installations and any problems with leasing, permitting, siting, or production that will prevent meeting the goal. In addition, the
shall make suggestions to help meet any shortfalls in meeting the production goals.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall complete a programmatic environmental impact statement. short-title.#text: National Petroleum Reserve Alaska Access Act

text.#text: This title may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that—

text.#text: It is the sense of

header.#text: Sense of Congress and reaffirming national policy for the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska

text.#text: the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska remains explicitly designated, both in name and legal status, for purposes of providing oil and natural gas resources to the United States; and

accordingly, the national policy is to actively advance oil and gas development within the Reserve by facilitating the expeditious exploration, production, and transportation of oil and natural gas from and through the Reserve.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended to read as follows:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 107(a) of the Naval Petroleum Reserves Production Act of 1976
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Naval Petroleum Reserves Production Act of 1976/s:107/ss:a

header.#text: National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska: lease sales

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall conduct an expeditious program of competitive leasing of oil and gas in the reserve in accordance with this Act. Such program shall include at least one lease sale annually in those areas of the reserve most likely to produce commercial quantities of oil and natural gas each year in the period 2013 through 2023.

text.#text: The

header.#text: National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska: planning and permitting pipeline and road construction

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in consultation with other appropriate Federal agencies, shall facilitate and ensure permits, in a timely and environmentally responsible manner, for all surface development activities, including for the construction of pipelines and roads, necessary to—

text.#text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the
develop and bring into production any areas within the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska that are subject to oil and gas leases; and

transport oil and gas from and through the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska in the most direct manner possible to existing transportation or processing infrastructure on the North Slope of Alaska.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that any Federal permitting agency shall issue permits in accordance with the following timeline:

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has issued a permit to drill shall be approved within 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act.

text.#text: Permits for such construction for transportation of oil and natural gas produced under existing Federal oil and gas leases with respect to which the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: of a request for a permit to drill.

text.#text: Permits for such construction for transportation of oil and natural gas produced under Federal oil and gas leases shall be approved within 6 months after the submission to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to

a plan for approved rights-of-way for a plan for pipeline, road, and any other surface infrastructure that may be necessary infrastructure that will ensure that all leasable tracts in the Reserve are within 25 miles of an approved road and pipeline right-of-way that can serve future development of the Reserve.

text.#text: To ensure timely future development of the Reserve, within 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

header.#text: Internet-based onshore oil and gas lease sales

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may conduct onshore lease sales through Internet-based bidding methods. Each individual Internet-based lease sale shall conclude within 7 days.

text.#text: In order to diversify and expand the Nation’s onshore leasing program to ensure the best return to the Federal taxpayer, reduce fraud, and secure the leasing process, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Lands Jobs and Energy Security Act of 2013/s:4002/ss:a

the findings of the analysis. The report shall include—

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the tenth Internet-based lease sale conducted under the amendment made by
estimates on increases or decreases in such lease sales, compared to sales conducted by oral bidding, in—
the number of bidders;
the average amount of bid;
the highest amount bid; and
the lowest bid;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: as a result of such sales, compared to sales conducted by oral bidding; and

text.#text: an estimate on the total cost or savings to the

an evaluation of the demonstrated or expected effectiveness of different structures for lease sales which may provide an opportunity to better maximize bidder participation, ensure the highest return to the Federal taxpayers, minimize opportunities for fraud or collusion, and ensure the security and integrity of the leasing process.

text.#text: Nothing in the

Any energy related action must be filed not later than the end of the 60-day period beginning on the date of the final agency action. Any energy related action not filed within this time period shall be barred.
All energy related actions—
shall be brought in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia; and
shall be resolved as expeditiously as possible, and in any event not more than 180 days after such cause of action is filed.

An interlocutory order or final judgment, decree or order of the district court in an energy related action may be reviewed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals shall resolve such appeal as expeditiously as possible, and in any event not more than 180 days after such interlocutory order or final judgment, decree or order of the district court was issued.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , no award may be made under
, or under

, and no amounts may be obligated or expended from the Claims and Judgment Fund of the United States Treasury to pay any fees or other expenses under such sections, to any person or party in an energy related action.

text.#text: Notwithstanding

In any energy related action in which the plaintiff does not ultimately prevail, the court shall award to the defendant (including any intervenor-defendants), other than the United States, fees and other expenses incurred by that party in connection with the energy related action, unless the court finds that the position of the plaintiff was substantially justified or that special circumstances make an award unjust. Whether or not the position of the plaintiff was substantially justified shall be determined on the basis of the administrative record, as a whole, which is made in the energy related action for which fees and other expenses are sought.

any Indian Tribe, or any organization of two or more entities, at least one of which is an Indian tribe, to conduct activities involving the exploration, development, production or transportation of oil, gas, coal, shale gas, oil shale, geothermal resources, wind or solar resources, underground coal gasification, biomass, or the generation of electricity, regardless of where such activities are undertaken.

The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Title I—Federal Lands Jobs and Energy Security
Sec. 1002. Policies regarding buying, building, and working for America.
Subtitle A—Onshore oil and gas permit streamlining
Chapter 1—Application for Permits to Drill Process Reform
Sec. 1111. Permit to drill application timeline.
Sec. 1112. Solar and wind right-of-way rental reform.
Sec. 1131. Improve Federal energy permit coordination.
Sec. 1142. Exclusive venue for certain civil actions relating to covered energy projects.
Sec. 1144. Expedition in hearing and determining the action.
Sec. 1146. Limitation on injunction and prospective relief.
Chapter 5—Knowing America’s Oil and Gas Resources
Sec. 1151. Funding oil and gas resource assessments.
Subtitle B—Oil and gas leasing certainty
Sec. 1202. Minimum acreage requirement for onshore lease sales.
Sec. 1302. Effectiveness of oil shale regulations, amendments to resource management plans, and record of decision.
Sec. 2002. Onshore domestic energy production strategic plan.
Title III—National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska access
Sec. 3002. Sense of Congress and reaffirming national policy for the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska.
Sec. 3003. National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska: lease sales.
Sec. 3004. National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska: planning and permitting pipeline and road construction.
Sec. 3005. Issuance of a new integrated activity plan and environmental impact statement.
Sec. 3007. Deadlines under new proposed integrated activity plan.
Sec. 4002. Internet-based onshore oil and gas lease sales.
Sec. 5004. Environmental reviews of major Federal actions on Indian lands.
Sec. 5008. Leases of restricted lands for the Navajo Nation.
